column11: Are you willing to participate in the survey?
column12: We will ask you to create a unique identifier so the survey analysis team can identify repeated responses across years. Please respond with the first letter of your birth city, the third letter of your birth month, and the last two digits of your phone number. Example: someone born in Seattle, in March, phone (202) 123-4567 would answer SR67
column14: Did you support a USAID biodiversity program in the past year?
column15: What stage(s) in the Program Cycle were you supporting? (select all that apply)
column16: What best describes your role in the USAID biodiversity program you supported most recently? (choose one)
column17: Please indicate the USAID operating unit you were associated with when serving in this role.
column18: I believe the use of adaptive management improves biodiversity program outcomes.
column19: I believe adaptive management is difficult.

column28: I believe the operating unit is committed to operationalizing adaptive management across its biodiversity programs.
column29: I believe the operating unit’s environment team generally has access to adequate time, financial, and human resources to adaptively manage biodiversity programs.
column30: I believe most biodiversity programs are designed and implemented using adaptive management.
column31: I believe most teams managing biodiversity programs have the knowledge, skills, and abilities they need to implement strategies for generating and applying evidence to strengthen program design and implementation.
column32: I believe most teams managing biodiversity programs have adequate resources (time, budget, staff, and access to technical assistance) to implement strategies for generating and applying evidence to strengthen program designs and implementation.
column33: A situation model is a diagram that displays the findings from a context/problem analysis to convey the most important threats and drivers affecting selected biodiversity focal interests. Most biodiversity teams develop and use situation models to guide the design of their programs.
column34: How important is it for biodiversity program teams to develop and use situation models to guide the design of their programs?
column35: Results chains and other types of logic models are used to represent the outcomes needed to achieve the theory of change for a USAID strategy or program. Most biodiversity program teams use results chains or other logic models to describe their theory of change and how their interventions work.
column36: How important is it for biodiversity program teams engaged in the design and implementation of biodiversity programs to develop results chains or other logic models to describe their theory of change and how their interventions work?
column37: Performance monitoring reveals if desired results are occurring and if implementation is on track.Most biodiversity program teams consider monitoring data when making decisions about adapting implementation of their programs.
column38: How important is it for biodiversity program teams to consider monitoring data when making decisions about adapting implementation of their programs?
column39: Evaluation is the systematic collection and analysis of information about the characteristics and outcomes of programs.Most biodiversity program teams review and apply evaluation findings to the design and implementation of their programs.
column40: How important is it for program teams to review and apply evaluation findings to the design and implementation of biodiversity programs?
column41: How familiar are you with the Office of Forestry and Biodiversity’s Measuring Impact (MI) and/or Measuring Impact II (MI2) activities?
column42: Have you or your team received support from Measuring Impact (MI) and/or Measuring Impact II (MI2)?
column43: Which statement best describes your role on the team receiving support from Measuring Impact (MI) and/or Measuring Impact II (MI2)? Please answer for your most recent engagement with MI or MI2.
column44: During which stage in the Program Cycle did you or your team engage with MI/MI2?
column45: Consider your most recent experience receiving Measuring Impact (MI) or Measuring Impact II (MI2) technical assistance for a C/RDCS. To what extent did MI/MI2 technical assistance affect the quality of the C/RDCS produced by your team?
column46: Consider your most recent experience receiving Measuring Impact (MI) or Measuring Impact II (MI2) technical assistance for a project design. To what extent did MI/MI2 technical assistance affect the quality of the Project Appraisal Document or PAD produced by your team?

column49: Consider your most recent experience receiving Measuring Impact (MI) or Measuring Impact II (MI2) technical assistance (e.g. Pause and Reflect) for an implemented activity.To what extent did MI/MI2 technical assistance affect the actions undertaken during implementation of the activity?

column25: I have two concerns. First is that the resources for adaptive management are not as well-developed as those for design, and it's sometimes hard to know where to turn to get information. Second, people become invested in conservation activities, like any activity, and there is a certain degree of path dependence in the real world that makes it difficult to shift course in a dramatic fashion.

column21: I understand adaptive management.  I think I'm good with "big picture" adaptive management, e.g., big-picture rethinks due to a coronavirus pandemic.  Where I'm not so good is using quarterly or annual monitoring against indicators/targets and making smaller course corrections.
column23: Adaptive management isn't something that any of us do alone.  I might agree with the statement "I believe WE can overcome barriers..."  It takes an institutional structure that highly values MEL.  It takes an institutional structure that can accept uncertainty (what IS versus what COULD BE).  It takes adept project managers and technical advisors.  Takes a village.

column21: Changing the approaches, the way of doing business are very important to cope and mitigate risks from the changing of climate, policy, context and especially during the pandemic, and post disasters.
column23: There are some barriers that we can mitigate their impacts but not to eliminate it. But adaptive management is very important for managing the Activity as a COR/AOR. We need to see how the changes may impact the Activity that we are managing, and find the ways to address, mitigate or learn from it to avoid the same mistakes in the future.
